titleStmt.title: Tungstate scheelites at high pressures. Part II: SrWO 4 Experiment number: HS2120

analytic.title: Tungstate scheelites at high pressures. Part II: SrWO 4 Experiment number: HS2120

div.p: At ambient conditions, strontium tungstate SrWO 4 has the scheelite CaWO 4 structure (I4 1 /a, Z = 4) with the Sr 2+ and W 6+ cations eightfold and fourfold coordinated by oxygens, respectively. Recently, Christofilos et al. [1] have reported a reversible pressure-induced phase transition in SrWO 4 starting at 11.5 GPa as observed with Raman scattering. Several Raman bands have a non-linear behavior in the pressure range 11.5-15 GPa, that can be due to either a stabilization of the high-pressure polymorph or a formation of an additional (intermediate) phase. The crystal structure of the modification above 15 GPa, with distorted WO 4 2-tetrahedra, is supposedly related to the scheelite type. In the synchrotron angle-dispersive x-ray powder diffraction study on CaWO 4 , the archetype for all the MeWO 4 (Me: Ca, Sr, Ba, Pb) compounds [2], it has been found that calcium tungstate (I4 1 /a, Z = 4) transforms to the fergusonite structure (I2/a, Z = 4), a distorted variant of the scheelite type, above about 10 GPa at room temperature. Both scheelite (I4 1 /a, Z = 4) and fergusonite (I2/a, Z = 4) structures are ordered superstructures of the fluorite type (Fm 3 m, Z = 4) and there is no discontinuity in the pressure dependence of the unit cell volumes during the I4 1 /a → I2/a transformation. Christofilos et al. [3] have earlier demonstrated that the low-energy Raman active modes in calcium tungstate exhibit softening during this phase transition. It is still not clear whether the scheelite → fergusonite structural change in CaWO 4 is of the first or second order. On the other hand, the temperature-induced I4 1 /a → I2/a transformation in rare earth niobates and tantalates at atmospheric conditions is ferroelastic and associated with the anisotropic phonon softening of a transverse acoustic mode at the Brillouin zone center [4].

In this study, we investigate the pressure-induced phase transitions in SrWO 4 scheelite at room temperature as observed with synchrotron angle-dispersive x-ray powder diffraction in diamond anvil cells.

A sample of polycrystalline SrWO 4 scheelite (99.9+%, Chempur Feinchemikalien und Forschungsbedarf GmbH, Karlsruhe) has been finely ground in ethanol and loaded into a diamond anvil cell with a mixture of methanol and ethanol as a pressure transmitting medium, already used for Raman scattering experiments [1].

Angle-dispersive powder x-ray diffraction patterns have been measured at room temperature on the ID09a beamline. Monochromatic radiation at 0.41325 Å has been used for pattern collection on image plates. The images have been integrated using the program FIT2D [5] to yield intensity versus 2θ diagrams. The ruby luminescence method [6] has been used for pressure measurements.
X-ray powder patterns of SrWO 4 collected upon compression to 20.7 GPa are shown in Figures 1 and 2.

Up to 8.8 GPa, the stable structure is of the scheelite type (I4 1 /a, Z = 4). At higher pressures between 10.7 and 14.2 GPa, new weak reflections occur (Figure 2) that can fully be accounted for with the fergusonite type (I2/a, Z = 4) already observed for CaWO 4 above 10 GPa [2]. Several additional new x-ray peaks are detectable in the pressure range 15-20.7 GPa. They correspond neither to the fergusonite type nor to the PbWO 4 -III (P2 1 /n, Z = 8), LaTaO 4 (P2 1 /c, Z = 4), HgWO 4 (C2/c, Z = 4), or BaMnF 4 (Cmc2 1 , Z = 4) types previously considered as candidates for the pressure-induced post-scheelite structures [2,7]. Moreover, the patterns collected between 15 and 20.7 GPa cannot be indexed on a basis of a single SrWO 4 phase. The pressureinduced transformations are irreversible as several "non-scheelite" reflections are observed at atmospheric conditions. In fact, some of them are due to the WO 3 and SrO impurities that (upon close inspection of Figures 1 and 3) seem to be occurring upon compression above 15 GPa. It suggests that SrWO 4 tends to decompose above 15 GPa.

A Rietveld refinement of the pattern for SrWO 4 collected at 10.7 GPa has been carried out with the structural model of the CaWO 4 fergusonite (I2/a, Z = 4) [2] using the program JANA2000 [8] (Figure 4 and Table 1). The refined parameters have included the lattice parameters, fractional atomic coordinates, isotropic thermal parameters for the Sr and W atoms, overall intensity scaling factor, zero shift, GP and LX parameters for the pseudo-Voigt profile function. The isotropic thermal parameters O atoms have been fixed at 0.015 and not refined. The agreement factors are: R p = 0.0347, wR p = 0.0511, GoF = 0.9, R obs = 0.0883, and wR obs = 0.0639. The Sr atoms are eightfold coordinated to the oxygen atoms. The W-O bond lengths and the nextnearest-neighbour distances are 1.75-1.85 Å and 2.66-2.94 Å, respectively. Hence, the WO 4 2-tetrahedra are deformed but still isolated.

Figure 5 shows the pressure dependence of lattice parameters, unit-cell volumes, and c/a axial ratios for the scheelite (I4 1 /a, Z = 4) and fergusonite (I2/a, Z = 4) polymorphs of SrWO 4 to 14.2 GPa extracted from the x-ray powder patterns (Figure 1) using the Le Bail method. The compression data including both phases of strontium tungstate cannot be fitted by a common Birch-Murnaghan equation of state. The unit-cell volumes at pressures up to 8.2 GPa are fitted with the zero-pressure bulk modulus B 0 = 66 ± 2 GPa, the first pressure derivative of the bulk modulus B' = 8.13 ± 5.1, and the unit-cell volume of scheelite at ambient pressure V 0 = 350.3 ± 1.74 Å 3 . When B' is fixed at 4.0, the B 0 and V 0 parameters are 81 ± 4 GPa and 349.1 ± 1.0 Å 3 , respectively. There is no significant volume collapse at the scheelite-fergusonite phase transition between 8.8 and 10.7 GPa. However, the fergusonite unit cells are less compressible than the scheelite ones. The c/a axial ratio is a measure of the tetragonal distortion of the fluorite superstructure, the ideal value being equal to 2.
This ratio in scheelite as well as the b/a and b/c ratios in fergusonite decrease upon compression, indicating that SrWO 4 is more compressible along its unique crystallographic axis.

The results of our angle-dispersive x-ray powder diffraction investigations demonstrate that SrWO 4 scheelite (I4 1 /a, Z = 4) transforms to fergusonite (I2/a, Z = 4) at about 10 GPa with the onset of decomposition above 15 GPa. The I4 1 /a → I2/a transformation has already been observed not only in CaWO 4 [2] but also in BaWO 4 [9] and CaMoO 4 [10].

Our findings that SrWO4 decomposes at high pressures correspond to what has already been observed in several other materials. Silicate zircons (ZrSiO 4 , HfSiO 4 ) and monazites, e.g., naturally dimorphous ThSiO 4 as thorite and huttonite [11], transform to scheelite structures and then, in some cases, decompose to component oxides under high-pressure conditions [12][13][14]. Similar behaviour is also evident from the work carried out on hydrothermally-prepared zircon and scheelite forms of ZrGeO 4 at high temperatures [15] and on fluoride scheelites [16].
2.18 2.19 2.20 2.21 b/a b/c c/a Axial ratios (relative units) Pressure (GPa) 0 2 4 6 8 10 12 14 310 315 320 325 330 335 340 345 350 Volume (A 3 ) Pressure (GPa)

figure.head: Figure 1
figure.figDesc: Figure 1Selected x-ray powder patterns of SrWO 4 upon compression.

figure.head: Figure 2
figure.figDesc: Figure 2Selected x-ray powder patterns of SrWO 4 upon compression in the 2θ region from 3.8° to 4.5°. The dashed line shows the pressure shift of the (020) reflection in the fergusonite structure (I2/a, Z = 4).

figure.head: Figure 3 X
figure.figDesc: Figure 3X-ray powder patterns of SrWO 4 upon decompression.

figure.head: Figure 4
figure.figDesc: Figure 4 Observed, calculated, and difference x-ray powder patterns for fergusonite SrWO 4 at 10.7 GPa (λ = 0.41325 Å) -I2/a, a = 5.2494(5) Å, b = 11.3759(8) Å, c = 5.2756(4) Å, β = 90.16(1)°, V = 315.04(5) Å 3 . Vertical markers indicate Bragg reflections.

figure.head: Figure 5
figure.figDesc: Figure 5Pressure dependence of lattice parameters of SrWO 4 . Full and open symbols represent the parameters for the scheelite (I4 1 /a, Z = 4) and fergusonite (I2/a, Z = 4) polymorphs, respectively.

figure.head: Table 1
figure.figDesc: Structural parameters of fergusonite SrWO 4 at 10.7 GPa: I2/a, a = 5.2494(5) Å, b = 11.3759(8) Å, c = 5.2756(4) Å, β = 90.16(1)°, V = 315.04(5) Å 3 .
